original_title: Mapping the Depths with an Autonomous Solar Boat
original_content:
Ever look out at a pond, stream, or river, and wonder how deep it is? For large bodies of water that are considered navigable, its easy enough to pull up a chart and find out. But what if theres no public data for the area youre interested in?
Well, you could spend all day on a little boat taking depth readings and making your own chart, but if youre anything like [Clay] you could build a solar-powered autonomous robot to do it for you. Hes been working on the boat, which he calls Gumption Trap, for the better part of a year now. If we had to guess, wed say the experience of designing and building it has ended up being a bit more interesting to him than the actual depth of the water  but thats fine by us.
The design of the boat is surprisingly economical, as far as marine designs go. Two capped four-inch PVC pipes are used as pontoons, and 3D printed brackets attach those to an aluminum extrusion frame that holds the electronics and solar panel high above the water. This arrangement provides an exceptionally stable platform that would be all but impossible to flip under normal circumstances.
Around the back of the craft, theres a pair of massive 3D printed thrusters, complete with some remarkably chunky printed propellers. The lack of rudders keeps things simple, with differential thrust between the two motors enough to keep the Gumption pointed in the right direction.

A waterproof container holds the batteries, solar charge controller, radio gear (for manual control), and the main computer. That computer is a custom PCB containing various modules that make up the brains of the operation. That includes a Teensy microcontroller, a GPS, compass, and a Ping echo sounder from Blue Robotics that [Clay] says cost more than the rest of the project put together. But of course you get what you pay for, and its hard to argue it wasnt worth the investment when you look at the impressive 3D depth maps hes managed to produce with the data it spits out.

For anyone looking to set sail with a similar craft, [Clay] has provided the source code for his boat, the board files for his custom PCB, and even the MATLAB code used to graph the depth data. Hes also put together the trio of videos below, which document the construction of the boat over the last eight months. The videos provide an interesting look at how the design has matured over time.
This isnt the first PVC pontoon boat to have graced these pages, last year we covered a similar design from [wesgood] thats also worth taking a look at if youre thinking of building your own robotic watercraft.
title: 太陽光発電で動く自律ロボットボートが水深を測定
body: どのくらい深いか気になることがありますか？河川や湖に関しては地図で検索できますが、情報がない場合どうしますか？ [Clay]さんはそのために太陽光発電ロボットを作りました。デザインは経済的で安定しています。さまざまなモジュールがあるカスタムのPCBを使用しています。
